messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:56): Maybe RDFa really should have been defined in two documents, a generic RDFa Concepts one and an RDFa in XHTML Syntax one
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:57): Currently those two parts seem to be confused and mixed together
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:57): At this point I'm tempted to say "or maybe zero documents"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:57): which causes problems when trying to write an RDFa in HTML Syntax one

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:59): Every post seems to echo the same sentiment: "It doesn't matter, the implementations will magically do the right thing without the spec having to state what it is"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:59): So if magic is making it work, why have a spec at all?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:08): wonders if it's sometimes preferable to attribute to malice rather than ignorance to avoid making people look stupid
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:10): http://damowmow.com/playground/htmlwg/chart.html
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (15:12): you're supposed to be asleep :)
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (15:12): graph seems to be heading in the right direction though

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:19): (in Firefox 3.5)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:20): Also, I can't see the "closed" colour unless I move my head downwards by six inches

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:22): you need a better monitor
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:23): So someone needs to start doing some reviewing
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:23): I have a better monitor than I had a month ago
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:23): Maybe you have a good monitor but at the wrong angle
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:24): except now it's glossy, so I can't look at it straight on because I'll see my face and get distracted, so I have to look downwards at a bit of an angle
1283c605cb56199444bcd570b62dd54a (15:30): Glossy monitors are broken by design.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:31): 1283c605cb56199444bcd570b62dd54a, glossy monitors with good anti-reflective coating on them aren't that bad
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:32): glossy and anti-reflective seem mutually exclusive
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:32): glossy monitors are evil

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:34): not entirely. You would get the glass cover over the LCD, like on the new MacBooks with glossy display, but that glass can be coated with anti-reflective coating so it looks glossy without reflecting everything
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:34): doesn't like it, but the computer was pretty cheap so he can't expect it to be great
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:35): hasn't inspected the latest MacBooks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:36): but the screen on the MacBooks that were current in Q2 of 2008 sucks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:36): I run mine lid closed except when traveling, so it's not a huge problem
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:37): also, the LED Cinema Display sucks
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:37): I have an iMac with a glossy display, and the screen on that really isn't bad at all
1283c605cb56199444bcd570b62dd54a (15:38): The only glossy screen I have is on my phone, but I can tolerate it only because it's full of OLED awesomeness.
9fb85f711fbcd18e915adc1cde75bdfa (15:38): I like my macbook pro glossy screen‚Ä¶ what exactly has that to do with HTML?
9fb85f711fbcd18e915adc1cde75bdfa (15:38): ;)
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:39): you cannot see the HTML without the glossy monitor
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:40): It's more like you cannot see the HTML issues graph with a glossy monitor which prevents you from looking straight on and therefore causes colour distortion
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:40): Maybe HTML should make glossy monitors non-conforming
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:40): i can't see the issues graph because of my browser, my ips panel rocks though

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:05): Just so I don't forget this link: "The BBC is publishing RDFa in the form of program reviews" is for the music reviews linked from http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/ (not TV programme reviews)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Looks like the licensing information isn't RFDa
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:08): s/TV programme reviews/TV programme listings/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:09): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I don't think RDFa has a requirement saying "You MUST use RDFa for absolutely all metadata on your page"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:09): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Seems they're just using RDFa that has an actual effect, i.e. Google's RDFa-ish review markup

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:09): heycam: "Need to test how implementations actually behave when passed too few or too many arguments." - i'd like this to be resolved, so i know how to write a test for new Worker()
